[[Keith Lindsay Stewart]] |anniversaries= |decorations= |battle_honours= }} The '''5th Infantry Brigade''' was an [[infantry]] [[brigade]] formation of the [[New Zealand Army|New Zealand Military Forces]], active during [[World War II]] as part of the [[2nd New Zealand Division]]. It saw service during the [[Battle of Greece]], the [[Battle of Crete]], the [[North African Campaign]] and the [[Italian Campaign (World War II)|Italian Campaign]] before being disbanded in late 1945. ==History== {{command structure |name= Order of Battle, 5th Infantry Brigade{{sfn|Pugsley|2014|p=55}} |date=c. 1940 |parent=[[2nd New Zealand Division]] |subordinate= * [[21st Battalion (New Zealand)|21st Battalion]] * [[22nd Battalion (New Zealand)|22nd Battalion]] * [[23rd Battalion (New Zealand)|23rd Battalion]] }} Shortly after the outbreak of the war, the [[Government of New Zealand|New Zealand government]] authorised the formation of a 'Special Force', what would later be designed the Second New Zealand Expeditionary Force, of 6,600 men for service overseas.{{sfn|Pugsley|2014|p=16}} After consultation with the [[Government of the United Kingdom|British government]], it was decided that New Zealand's primary contribution to the war effort would be in the form of an infantry division.{{sfn|Pugsley|2014|p=19}} The 5th Infantry Brigade was the second of the three echelons of the [[2nd New Zealand Division]].{{sfn|McClymont|1959|p=43}} Commanded by [[Brigadier]] [[James Hargest]], the brigade consisted of three infantry battalions, these being the [[21st Battalion (New Zealand)|21st]] (with men drawn from the Auckland Military District), the [[22nd Battalion (New Zealand)|22nd]] (Central Military District), and the [[23rd Battalion (New Zealand)|23rd]] (South Island Military District).{{sfn|Pugsley|2014|p=22}} The brigade left for the Middle East in May 1940{{sfn|McClymont|1959|pp=29–30}} but while en route to Aden, the news of the invasion of Holland and Belgium prompted the diversion of the troop convoy to England by way of Cape Town.{{sfn|McClymont|1959|p=31}} It arrived in mid-June and formed part of the country's defences.{{sfn|McClymont|1959|pp=32–33}} ===Greece=== The start of the Greece campaign marked the division's first offensive operations as a complete formation. Sent to Greece alongside the [[6th Division (Australia)|Australian 6th Division]] and a British armoured brigade in order to support the Greeks in their defence against an expected invasion by the Germans, the New Zealanders manned the Aliakmon Line,{{sfn|McGibbon|2000|pp=204–209}} with the 5th Brigade remaining in reserve in Athens until it moved to Olympus Pass, its designated defensive position.{{sfn|McClymont|1959|pp=142–143}} ==Notes== ;Footnotes {{reflist|group=Note}} ;Citations {{reflist|3}} ==References== {{refbegin}} *{{cite book|last=McClymont|first=W.
